body:
So, is `WordSpecLike` removed in 3.1.0? Looks like we use it in more places than that so it would be more work than just a dependency bump.

As a workaround you should be able to skip `PluginSpec` and use `akka.testkit.TestKitBase` yourself with some minimal glue.
`PluginSpec` is part of the `akka-persistence-tck`, for example via `JournalSpec` so I think it's a valid request.

So since scalatest did not keep binary compatibility we have the choice between forcing users to stay on 3.0.x or forcing users to update to 3.1.x .

Indeed since this only affects the testkit/tck projects it seems :+1: to move to 3.1.x

issue.title: Update scalatest to 3.1.0

repository.name: akka-persistence-jdbc
repository.description: Asynchronously writes journal and snapshot entries to configured JDBC databases so that Akka Actors can recover state

issue.body:
Updates [org.scalatest:scalatest](https://github.com/scalatest/scalatest) [from 3.0.8 to 3.1.0](https://github.com/scalatest/scalatest/compare/release-3.0.8...release-3.1.0).
[Release Notes/Changelog](https://github.com/scalatest/scalatest/releases/tag/release-3.1.0)

I'll automatically update this PR to resolve conflicts as long as you don't change it yourself.

If you'd like to skip this version, you can just close this PR. If you have any feedback, just mention me in the comments below.

Have a fantastic day writing Scala!

<details>
<summary>Ignore future updates</summary>

Add this to your `.scala-steward.conf` file to ignore future updates of this dependency:
```
updates.ignore = [ { groupId = "org.scalatest", artifactId = "scalatest" } ]
```
</details>
<details>
<summary>Applied Migrations</summary>

* https://raw.githubusercontent.com/scalatest/autofix/e4de53fa40fac423bd64d165ff36bde38ce52388/3.0.x/rules/src/main/scala/org/scalatest/autofix/v3_0_x/RenameDeprecatedPackage.scala
* https://raw.githubusercontent.com/scalatest/autofix/e4de53fa40fac423bd64d165ff36bde38ce52388/3.1.x/rules/src/main/scala/org/scalatest/autofix/v3_1_x/RewriteDeprecatedNames.scala
</details>

body: Hi, I tried to use Scalafix as proposed in ScalaTest migration guide, was not able to add it to the project without changes in the build. Is there any good reason to use such old sbt version? Would it be ok, if I try to migrate to the latest sbt-0.13.x (I suppose this must be easier) or sbt-1.x in scope of this issue?
@limansky Not sure if this relates to this issue? Akka is on sbt 1.3
#26989 can serve as some inspiration (though it probably has too many merge conflicts to be useful code-wise)
@johanandren oh, stupid me. I didn't realized that I already had a fork and it was pretty old.

issue.body:
This changes is migration to ScalaTest 3.1.0, see #28289. Generally only imports and class names were changed.

If the same changes is required for 2.5.x branch, feel free to ask me.

body: Hi! I've created pull request on master, but possible it also have to be ported to version 2.5.x and to akka-http. I'm not really sure about that. Th problem is that it is binary incompatible, so, for example, it fails MiMa check.

Users of `ScalaTestWithActorTestKit` in `akka-actor-testkit` need to migrate, or create their own copy of the 2.6.1 version of [ScalaTestWithActorTestKit](https://github.com/akka/akka/blob/v2.6.1/akka-actor-testkit-typed/src/main/scala/akka/actor/testkit/typed/scaladsl/ScalaTestWithActorTestKit.scala).

issue.title: ScalaTest 3.2.0

labels.name: discuss
labels.description: Tickets that need some discussion before proceeding. Not decided if it's a good idea.

repository.name: akka-core
repository.description: A platform to build and run apps that are elastic, agile, and resilient. SDK, libraries, and hosted environments.

issue.body:
A new binary incompatible version of ScalaTest, 3.2.0, is out.

This impacts the users of our testkit and TCK projects.

Like with 3.1.0 (#28289) the dilemma is between forcing users to stay on 3.1.0 or forcing users to update to 3.2.0.

With 3.1.0 we expected this to be painful when users would try to mix different testkits, but it seems this turned out fairly smooth. To keep this smooth, perhaps we should stick with the 'old' groupId/artifactId for now, rather than using the more fine-grained dependencies, to give downstream projects a chance to catch up.
